Empires & Puzzles Liu Tang Hero Review & Strategy Guide
Is Liu Tang the new Shrubbear? This 3-star Outlaw brings a 5-turn Taunt, critical hits, and a passive that punishes stronger enemies. Find out if this burly bandit deserves a spot in your roster.
Liu Tang: The Red-Haired Devil Who Loves to Get Hit
Meet Liu Tang, the "Red-Haired Devil of Water Margin," a Rare (3-star) Fire hero hailing from the
family. Released in May 2025, this burly bandit brings a mechanic previously reserved for the elite few to the 3-star arena:
. While he moves at a ponderous
speed, his ability to redirect enemy fire for a whopping 5 turns makes him a strategic powerhouse. He's essentially a angry, red-headed wall that hits back.

Liu Tang certainly lives up to his nickname. The artwork features a rugged, imposing figure with a wild mane of red hair and a matching beard that screams "I woke up like this, and I'm ready to fight." He wields a massive blade that looks like it could slice through a tank (which is ironic, because

is the tank). The vibrant red tones fit his element perfectly, and his expression suggests he's not the type to negotiate. It's a classic Wuxia warrior aesthetic—bold, loud, and undeniably aggressive.
When we look at Liu Tang's stats, it's clear his build is focused on survival. With
(base), he is incredibly sturdy for a 3-star hero.
To put this in perspective with the modern meta (late 2025), let's compare him to recent 3-star releases:

Liu Tang holds his own. His defense is right up there with the latest power-creep heroes, and while his health is slightly lower than the brand-new "Temple" heroes like Ali, it's still well above the average for older 3-stars. His

is on the lower side, but given his primary role is to soak up damage, this is a fair trade-off. He is built to take a beating, not necessarily to dish one out—though his special skill has something to say about that.
is a multi-faceted skill that does three things, but let's be honest, we're all here for one of them.
. This is huge. In 3-star tournaments, especially Rush Attack, preventing enemies from targeting your squishy snipers or healers for five whole turns is often a win condition.
to the target and minor damage to nearby enemies. It's not a nuke, but it's a decent "get off my lawn" slap.
This is the family's signature gimmick. The special skill has a

to deal critical hits (50% more damage). If it crits, it also reduces max health. It's a nice bonus when it happens, but don't build your strategy around it. It's the cherry on top of the Taunt sundae.
Slow (12 tiles). In Rush Attack tournaments, this becomes Very Fast (6.5 tiles), which is where he truly shines.
With 497 Attack, a 265% hit deals roughly
raw damage (before defense calculation). It's enough to finish off a wounded 3-star but won't one-shot anyone at full health.

5 Turns. This is longer than the standard 3 or 4 turns seen on many other Taunt heroes (like Shrubbear's 4 turns). This extra turn can be the difference between your healer charging up or your team getting wiped.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Outlaws of Liangshan family brings some very interesting mechanics to the table, making Liu Tang more than just a stats stick.
The family bonus boosts Critical Chance. While nice for tile damage, it's not a game-changer for a slow defensive hero unless you are running a mono-red team where his tiles might actually hurt.
This is where Liu Tang gets spicy.
This is arguably his best feature.
If he hits an enemy with higher HP, he heals himself (
by a special skill from an enemy with higher HP, he gains

In a format where enemies often have boosted health or just higher base stats (thanks to newer power creep), Liu Tang punishes them for attacking him. That mana gain helps mitigate his Slow speed outside of Rush formats.
A situational but welcome immunity, especially against Barbarian talents or specific bleed-heavy heroes.
If his special skill crits, he cleanses the team. Since this relies on RNG (crit chance), treat it as a happy accident rather than a reliable cleanse.
Taunt at the start of battle.

This is incredible. For 3 turns (or more depending on LB level), Liu Tang protects his team immediately. This prevents early snipes or status ailments from ruining your setup before you've even matched a tile. It essentially guarantees your team survives the opening salvo.
When Liu Tang was released in May 2025, he was immediately compared to
Shrubbear had a monopoly on this niche. Liu Tang offered a Fire alternative with better stats and a more offensive bite.
Even months later, Liu Tang remains relevant because Taunt is a mechanic that ages like fine wine. His stats are competitive with the "Glass" and "Temple" heroes of late 2025.

He is a staple for 3-star Rush Attack tournaments and a very strong contender in Bloody Battle (where his self-heal passive won't work, but his Taunt is invaluable). He is not "outdated" by any means.
As of this review, Liu Tang does not have a costume.
Liu Tang is a tank. You want him to stay alive as long as possible to keep that Taunt active.
Maximizes his survivability. Every point of defense makes his Taunt more effective.
His special skill damage becomes negligible.
Increases the damage of his special skill and the potential critical hit impact.
He dies faster. A dead Taunter is a useless Taunter.
. His job is to be a punching bag, so make him a high-quality, reinforced leather punching bag.
The most powerful defensive mechanic in the game, protecting the entire team.
Grants free mana when hit by stronger enemies, helping him charge faster than his "Slow" speed suggests.
The chance to Revive allows him to steal a win even after being knocked out.
Without Rush Attack rules or his passive triggering, he can be too slow to fire before the battle is decided.
His secondary effects (Crit damage, Cleanse) rely on chance, making them unreliable for strategic planning.
In Bloody Battle, his self-healing passive is nullified.
He is S-Tier here. The combination of Very Fast speed + Taunt is broken.
His Taunt counts as a buff, and he protects the buffers.
Useful for protecting your team against bosses with nasty single-target hits.
Faiez (Block Ailments) - Liu Tang (Taunt) - Treevil (The Destroyer) - Joukahainen (Dispel/Hit) - Kvasir (Minions)
Liu Tang draws fire while Faiez makes the team ailment-immune. Treevil kills everyone.
Buster increases damage taken, Liu Tang protects the team, and Waqas nukes the board.
Heroes like Tyrum (especially the Glass costume) or Mnesseus can strip his Taunt, leaving him vulnerable.
Minions can chip away at him, and he doesn't have a good way to clear them.
Don't run him with Shrubbear. You only need one Taunt active at a time.
. A 3-star Taunt hero is a rare commodity that will help you clear map stages and win tournament battles that you have no business winning otherwise. He is worth the hidden blades.
You likely have Shrubbear limit broken already. Do you need Liu Tang?

Having a Taunter in a different element allows you to color-stack effectively in tournaments or avoid being weak against a specific tank. His Aether Power (Auto-Taunt) alone makes him worth the Alpha Aethers for serious tournament competitors.
When Liu Tang was in Beta, he was even stronger. The developers nerfed his stats slightly and removed a "Healing over Time" effect from his special skill before release.
"Don't think this needed a nerf tbh, seems a bit weak now," lamented one player.

"Has this character been nerfed? Does anyone remember what the original version was like?"
Despite the nerfs, the community quickly realized that
, and even a "nerfed" Taunt hero is top-tier in the 3-star arena.

Liu Tang is a must-have hero for any serious Empires & Puzzles player. While he may look like a chaotic barbarian, his gameplay is all about control and protection. He forces the enemy to play by his rules, absorbing hits and buying your team precious time. In the world of 3-star heroes, where battles are often decided in a few turns, Liu Tang is the bouncer who decides who gets to hit whom.
A solid tank and a Rush Tournament superstar. Level him, limit break him, and watch him laugh as enemies waste their specials on his rugged, red-bearded face.
